Thy name rouses the heart of [[Punjab]], [[Sindh]], [[Gujarat]] and [[Maratha]], of the [[South India|Dravida]] and [[Odisha]] and [[Bengal]]; It echoes in the hills of [[Vindhya]] and the [[Himalayas]], and mingles in the music of [[Ganga]] and [[Yamuna]] and is chanted by the waves of the Indian sea. They pray for thy blessings and sing thy praise. The saving of all people waits in thy hands, Thou dispenser of India's destiny. Victory, Victory, Victory to thee.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=jfrWCQAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=The Complete Guide to National Symbols and Emblems [2 Volumes]|author=James Minahan|publisher= ABC-CLIO|page=61}}}} ==Gallery== File:The Morning Song of India.png|Tagore's translation of Jana Gana Mana on February 28, 1919 at the [[Besant Theosophical College]] File:English translation of Jana Gana Mana in Tagore's handwriting page 1.jpg|Page 1 of Tagore's translation of Jana Gana Mana on February 28, 1919 at the [[Besant Theosophical College]] File:English translation of Jana Gana Mana in Tagore's handwriting page 2.jpg|Page 2 of Tagore's translation of Jana Gana Mana on February 28, 1919 at the [[Besant Theosophical College]] File:Early or original score of Jana Gana Mana.jpg|Early or original score of Jana Gana Mana == Controversies == In [[Kerala]], students belonging to the [[Jehovah's Witnesses]] religious denomination were expelled by school authorities for their refusal to sing the national anthem on religious grounds, although they stood up respectfully when the anthem was sung.https://indiankanoon.org/docfragment/1508089/?formInput=national%20anthem%20case The [[Kerala High Court]] concluded that there was nothing in it which could offend anyone's religious susceptibilities, and upheld their expulsion. On 11 August 1986,https://www.jw.org/en/news/legal/by-region/india/supreme-court-national-anthem-free-speech/ the [[Supreme Court of India|Supreme Court]] reversed the High Court and ruled that the High Court had misdirected itself because the question is not whether a particular religious belief or practice appeals to our reason or sentiment but whether the belief is genuinely and conscientiously held as part of the profession or practice of a religion. "Our personal views and reactions are irrelevant" The Supreme Court affirmed the principle that it is not for a secular judge to sit in judgment on the correctness of a religious belief.{{cite web|title=To sing or not to sing Vande Mataram|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/to-sing-or-not-to-sing-vande-mataram--------/11912/|publisher=Indian Express|accessdate=16 December 2013}} Supreme Court observed in its ruling {{cite web | title =Bijoe Emmanuel & Ors V. State of Kerala & Ors [1986] INSC 167 | publisher =indiankanoon.org | date =11 August 1986 | url =http://www.indiankanoon.org/doc/1508089/ | doi = | accessdate = 16 December 2013}} {{quotation |"There is no provision of law which obliges anyone to sing the National Anthem nor is it disrespectful to the National Anthem if a person who stands up respectfully when the National Anthem is sung does not join the singing. Proper respect is shown to the National Anthem by standing up when the National Anthem is sung. It will not be right to say that disrespect is shown by not joining in the singing. Standing up respectfully when the National Anthem is sung but not singing oneself clearly does not either prevent the singing of the National Anthem or cause disturbance to an assembly engaged in such singing so as to constitute the offence mentioned in s. 3 of the [[Prevention of Insults to National Honour Act]]".}} On 30 November 2016, Supreme Court of India ordered the National Anthem must be played before movies in theaters, in order to instill "committed patriotism and nationalism".[http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-news-india/national-anthem-national-flag-supreme-court-theater-4402827/ Supreme Court orders National Anthem must be played before movies in theaters] On 10 February 2017, 2 Kashmiris were booked for not standing during anthem in Jammu Cinema, under provisions of the Prevention of Insults to National Honour Act, 1971. This was the first arrest of its kind made by a state government in India.[http://www.kashmirlife.net/2-kashmiris-booked-not-standing-anthem-jammu-cinema-131954/ 2 Kashmiris booked for not standing during anthem in Jammu Cinema][http://indianexpress.com/article/india/jk-in-a-first-state-govt-employee-among-two-arrested-for-not-standing-during-national-anthem/J&K: In a first, state govt employee amongst two arrested for not standing during national anthem] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170212092002/http://indianexpress.com/article/india/jk-in-a-first-state-govt-employee-among-two-arrested-for-not-standing-during-national-anthem/J%26K%3A/ |date=12 February 2017 }} In January 2018, the government reversed its stance and requested that the Supreme Court rescind the order until a government panel could consider the issue in more depth; the court agreed, and so around 9 January 2018 the National Anthem ceased being compulsory in movie theaters.{{cite news|title=India anthem not mandatory in cinemas|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-india-42618830|accessdate=10 January 2018|work=BBC News|date=2018}} === Historical significance === The composition was first sung during a convention of the [[Indian National Congress]] in [[Calcutta]] on 27 December 1911.{{cite web |url=http://www.countercurrents.org/comm-chatterjee310803.htm |title= Tagore and Jana Gana Mana |accessdate= |work=Monish R. Chatterjee}} It was sung on the second day of the convention, and the agenda of that day devoted itself to a loyal welcome of George V on his visit to India. The event was reported thus in the British Indian press:
"The Bengali poet [[Rabindranath Tagore]] sang a song composed by him specially to welcome the Emperor." (''Statesman'', Dec. 28, 1911)
"The proceedings began with the singing by [[Rabindranath Tagore]] of a song specially composed by him in honour of the Emperor." (''Englishman'', Dec. 28, 1911)
"When the proceedings of the Indian National Congress began on Wednesday 27th December 1911, a Bengali song in welcome of the Emperor was sung. A resolution welcoming the Emperor and Empress was also adopted unanimously." (''Indian'', Dec. 29, 1911)
====Counter arguments==== Many historians aver that the newspaper reports cited above were misguided. The confusion arose in British Indian press since a different song, "[[Badshah Humara]]" written in [[Hindi]] by Rambhuj Chaudhary,{{cite web |url=http://www.sacw.net/DC/CommunalismCollection/ArticlesArchive/pkDatta092004.html |title= India: Are we still singing for the Empire? |accessdate= |work=Pradip Kumar Datta}} was sung on the same occasion in praise of the monarch. The nationalist Indian press stated this difference of events clearly:
"The proceedings of the Congress party session started with a prayer in Bengali to praise God (song of benediction). This was followed by a resolution expressing loyalty to King George V. Then another song was sung welcoming King George V." (''[[Amrita Bazar Patrika]]'', Dec.28,1911)
"The annual session of Congress began by singing a song composed by the great Bengali poet Ravindranath Tagore. Then a resolution expressing loyalty to King George V was passed. A song paying a heartfelt homage to King George V was then sung by a group of boys and girls." (''The Bengalee'', Dec. 28, 1911)
Even the report of the annual session of the Indian National Congress of December 1911 stated this difference:
"On the first day of 28th annual session of the Congress, proceedings started after singing Vande Mataram. On the second day the work began after singing a patriotic song by Babu Ravindranath Tagore. Messages from well wishers were then read and a resolution was passed expressing loyalty to King George V. Afterwards the song composed for welcoming King George V and Queen Mary was sung."
On 10 November 1937 Tagore wrote a letter to Mr Pulin Bihari Sen about the controversy. That letter in Bengali can be found in Tagore's biography'' Ravindrajivani, volume II page 339'' by ''Prabhatkumar Mukherjee''.
"A certain high official in His Majesty's service, who was also my friend, had requested that I write a song of felicitation towards the Emperor. The request simply amazed me. It caused a great stir in my heart. In response to that great mental turmoil, I pronounced the victory in Jana Gana Mana of that Bhagya Bidhata [ed. God of Destiny] of India who has from age after age held steadfast the reins of India's chariot through rise and fall, through the straight path and the curved. That Lord of Destiny, that Reader of the Collective Mind of India, that Perennial Guide, could never be George V, George VI, or any other George. Even my official friend understood this about the song. After all, even if his admiration for the crown was excessive, he was not lacking in simple common sense."{{cite web|url=http://www.rareindianfacts.org/2012/12/controversy-surrounding-indian-national.html|title=Controversy Surrounding The Indian National Anthem|publisher=Rare India Fact|accessdate=23 June 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121218024543/http://www.rareindianfacts.org/2012/12/controversy-surrounding-indian-national.html|archivedate=18 December 2012|df=dmy-all}}
Again in his letter of 19 March 1939 Tagore writes:{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-india-16241465|title=BBC News – Indian anthem Jana Gana Mana turns 100|date=27 December 2011|publisher=Bbc.co.uk|accessdate=8 July 2012}}
"I should only insult myself if I cared to answer those who consider me capable of such unbounded stupidity as to sing in praise of George the Fourth or George the Fifth as the Eternal Charioteer leading the pilgrims on their journey through countless ages of the timeless history of mankind." ''(Purvasa, Phalgun, 1354, p. 738.)''
Moreover, Tagore was hailed as a patriot who wrote other songs too apart from "Jana Gana Mana" lionising the Indian independence movement. He renounced his knighthood in protest against the 1919 [[Jallianwala Bagh Massacre]]. The Knighthood (i.e. the title of 'Sir') was conferred on him by the same King George V after receiving the [[Nobel Prize in Literature]] for "[[Gitanjali]]" from the government of Sweden. Two of Tagore's more politically charged compositions, "[[Chitto Jetha Bhayshunyo]]" ("Where the Mind is Without Fear", Gitanjali Poem #35) and "[[Ekla Chalo Re]]" ("If They Answer Not to Thy Call, Walk Alone"), gained mass appeal, with the latter favoured by Gandhi and Netaji.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} === Regional aspects === Another controversy is that only those provinces that were under British rule, i.e. [[Punjab, India|Punjab]], [[Sind Province (1936–55)|Sindh]], [[Gujarat]], [[Maharashtra|Maratha]], [[Dravidian peoples|Dravid]] ([[South India]]), [[Odisha]]/[[Utkal]] and [[Bengal]], were mentioned. None of the princely states – [[Kashmir]], [[Rajasthan]], [[Hyderabad State|Hyderabad]], [[Kingdom of Mysore|Mysore]] or [[Kerala]] – or the states in [[Northeast India]], which are now integral parts of [[India]] were mentioned. But opponents of this proposition claim that [[Rabindranath Tagore|Tagore]] mentioned only the border states of [[India]] to include complete [[India]]. Whether the [[princely state]]s would form a part of a liberated [[India|Indian republic]] was a matter of debate even till [[Independence Day (India)|Indian Independence]]. 'Dravida' includes the people from the south (though Dravida specifically means Tamil and even then, the same consideration is not given for the south since there are many distinct people whereas in the north each of the distinct people are named) and 'Jolodhi' (Stanza 1) is Sanskrit for "seas and oceans". Even North-East which was under British rule or holy rivers apart from Ganges and Yamuna are not mentioned to keep the song in its rhythm. India has 29 states, 7 union territories. In 2005, there were calls to delete the word "Sindh" and substitute it with the word [[Kashmir]]. The argument was that [[Sindh]] was no longer a part of India, having become part of Pakistan as a result of the [[Partition of India|Partition]] of 1947. Opponents of this proposal hold that the word "Sindh" refers to the [[Indus river|Indus]] and to [[Sindhi people|Sindhi]] culture, and that Sindhi people are an integral part of India's cultural fabric. The [[Supreme Court of India]] declined to change the national anthem and the wording remains unchanged. On 17 December 2013, MLA of [[Assam]], [[Phani Bhushan Choudhury]] cited article of '[[The Times of India]]' published on 26 January 1950, stating that originally the word 'Kamarup' was included in the song, but was later changed to 'Sindhu' and claimed that Kamarup should be re-included.[http://www.assamtribune.com/scripts/detailsnew.asp?id=dec1813/at096 ''State to seek newspaper clarification on report''. STAFF Reporter. Assam Tribune, 17-12-2013] To this, the then minister [[Rockybul Hussain]] replied that the state government would initiate steps in this regard after response from the newspaper. The debate was further joined by the then minister [[Ardhendu Dey]], mentioning '[[Sanchayita]]' (edited by Tagore himself) etc. where he said Kamrup was not mentioned. ==See also== * [[Subh Sukh Chain]], the National Anthem of the [[Arzi Hukumat-e-Azad Hind|Provisional Government of Free India]] * [[Vande Mataram]], the National Song of India * [[Amar Shonar Bangla]], the National Anthem of Bangladesh * [[Indian National Army]] * Capt.[[Ram Singh Thakur]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Notes== {{Noteslist}} ==External links== {{Sister project links| wikt=no | commons=Category:Jana Gana Mana | b=no | n=no | q=no | s=Jana Gana Mana | v=no | voy=no | species=no | d=q83099}} * [http://knowindia.gov.in/national-identity-elements/national-anthem.php Know India: National anthem], Government of India website * {{cite wikisource|title=The Morning Song of India}}English translation of the hymn "Jana Gana Mana" in Tagore's handwriting {{Symbols of India}} {{Nationalanthemsofasia}} {{Rabindranath Tagore}} [[Category:Bengali-language literature]] [[Category:Rabindra Sangeet]] [[Category:Indian songs]] [[Category:Asian anthems]] [[Category:National symbols of India]] [[Category:Indian patriotic songs]] [[Category:Songs written by Rabindranath Tagore]] [[Category:Bengali-language songs]] [[Category:History of West Bengal]] [[Category:History of Kolkata]] [[Category:Bengali music]] [[Category:National anthems]] [[Category:Compositions in E-flat major]]

'''Sir John Schorne''' (died 1313) was [[Rector (ecclesiastical)|rector]] of [[North Marston]] in the [[England|English]] county of [[Buckinghamshire]]. He was a very pious man and was said to have effected many [[miracle|miraculous]] cures for [[gout]] and [[toothache]]. [[Image:NorthMarstonWell.JPG|right|120px|thumb|The Schorne Well at North Marston, Schorne Lane]]
During a [[drought]], he discovered a [[water well|well]], whose [[water]]s were reputed to have miraculous properties. His reputation for [[holy|holiness]] was such that he is believed to have cast the [[devil]] into a [[boot]]. He is often pictured holding a boot with a devil in it, which was [http://www.phrases.org.uk/meanings/jack-in-the-box.html thought to be the origin] of the child's [[jack-in-the-box]] toy. However, the toy did not come about until over 500 years after Schorne's time. When he died, his shrine in the church at North Marston became a popular place of [[pilgrim]]age and he was regarded by many as a [[saint]], although he was never canonised. His remains were later moved to [[St George's Chapel, Windsor]], the burial place of English monarchs. [[Henry VIII]], who was buried there, went on pilgrimage to Schorne's Well in July 1511<ref>http://journals.cambridge.org/download.php?file=%2F4297_3DA98D16DA42063CFD530E25714FEF88_journals__HIS_HIS57_01_S0018246X13000368a.pdf&cover=Y&code=e9c7530ec97e6fb550aadfcbedad50cd [[Richard Rex]], ''The Religion of Henry VIII'', p.8</ref> and May 1521.<ref>[[David Starkey]], p.7, ''Henry''</ref> The Holy Well was renovated in 2004/2005 and may still be seen in North Marston.
There was a rector in [[Princes Risborough]] called John de Schorne in circa 1289, according to the list of rectors in the front of the [[parish register]]. It is likely to be the same person, though this is difficult to confirm for certain.<ref>Princes Risborough Parish Register, held at the [[Centre for Buckinghamshire Studies]]</ref>
One of the two team [[benefice]]s in [[Claydon (deanery)|Claydon Deanery]] is named after Schorne to this day.

{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2015}} {{Infobox film | name = Koyaanisqatsi | image = Koyaanisqatsi poster.jpg | alt = A black film poster, reading in small print at the top "FRANCIS FORD COPPOLA PRESENTS" with "KOYAANISQATSI" in large red text, subtitled below with "LIFE OUT OF BALANCE" The white text in the middle reads "October 4, 1982. More than 5,000 people filled out the sold out Radio City Music Hall to experience a remarkable film event. That event was the world premiere of KOYAANISQATSI. Now everyone can share the power of that experience." Below that text, reads "DIRECTED BY Godfrey Reggio, MUSIC BY Philip Glass, CINEMATOGRAPHY BY Ron Fricke". Various logos are at the bottom of the poster. | director = [[Godfrey Reggio]] | producer = Godfrey Reggio | writer = {{Plainlist| * [[Ron Fricke]] * [[Michael Hoenig]] * Godfrey Reggio * Alton Walpole}} | music = [[Philip Glass]] | cinematography = Ron Fricke | editing = {{Plainlist| * Ron Fricke * Alton Walpole}} | studio = Institute for Regional Education
[[American Zoetrope]] | distributor = {{Plainlist| * Island Alive * New Cinema}} | released = {{Film date|1983|04|27}} (limited) | runtime = 85 minutes{{cite web | url=http://bbfc.co.uk/releases/koyaanisqatsi-1970-2 | title=''KOYAANISQATSI'' (U) | work=[[British Board of Film Classification]] | date=1983 | accessdate=April 19, 2015}} | country = United States | budget = | gross = $1.7 million{{cite web | url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=koyaanisqatsi.htm | title=Koyaanisqatsi (1983) | work=[[Box Office Mojo]] | publisher=[[Internet Movie Database]] | accessdate=April 19, 2015}} }} '''''Koyaanisqatsi''''' ({{IPAc-en|lang|pron|k|oʊ|j|ɑː|n|ɪ|s|ˈ|k|ɑː|t|s|iː}}), also known as '''''Koyaanisqatsi: Life Out of Balance''''', is a 1982 American [[experimental film]] directed by [[Godfrey Reggio]] with music composed by [[Philip Glass]] and cinematography by [[Ron Fricke]]. The film consists primarily of [[slow motion]] and [[time-lapse]] footage of cities and many natural landscapes across the [[United States]]. The visual [[Symphonic poem|tone poem]] contains neither [[dialogue]] nor a vocalized narration: its tone is set by the juxtaposition of images and music. Reggio explained the lack of dialogue by stating "it's not for lack of love of the language that these films have no words. It's because, from my point of view, our language is in a state of vast humiliation. It no longer describes the world in which we live."{{cite video |people=Carson, Greg (director) |date=2002 |title=Essence of Life |medium=DVD |publisher=[[MGM Home Entertainment]] }} In the [[Hopi language]], the word ''Koyaanisqatsi'' means "unbalanced life".{{cite web|url=http://philipglass.com/films/koyaanisqatsi/|title=Film: Koyaanisqatsi|accessdate=2017-01-26}} The film is the first in the [[Qatsi trilogy]] of films: it is followed by ''[[Powaqqatsi]]'' (1988) and ''[[Naqoyqatsi]]'' (2002). The [[trilogy]] depicts different aspects of the relationship between humans, nature and technology. ''Koyaanisqatsi'' is the best known of the trilogy and is considered a [[cult film]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.michigandaily.com/content/cult-koyaanisqatsi-blends-music-film|title=Cult ''Koyaanisqatsi'' blends music, film|work=The Michigan Daily|access-date=2018-02-12|language=en}} However, because of [[copyright]] issues, the film was [[out of print]] for most of the 1990s.{{cite web |url=http://www.spiritofbaraka.com/koyaanisqatsi |title=Koyaanisqatsi |work=Spirit of Baraka |date=2007-05-21 |accessdate=2008-05-28}} ==Synopsis== The first image in the film is of the Great Gallery [[pictograph]] in [[Horseshoe Canyon (Utah)|Horseshoe Canyon]], in [[Canyonlands National Park]], Utah. The section shown depicts several tall, shadowed figures standing near a taller figure adorned with a crown. The next image is a [[close-up]] of a [[Saturn V]] rocket during its launch ([[Apollo 11]]). The film fades into a shot of a desolate desert landscape. From there, it progresses to footage of various natural phenomena such as waves and clouds. The film's introduction to human involvement in the environment is a low aerial shot of choppy water, cutting to a similar shot of rows of cultivated flowers. After aerial views of monumental rock formations partly drowned by the artificial [[Lake Powell]], we see a large mining truck causing billows of black dust. This is followed by shots of [[electric power transmission|power lines]] in the desert. Man's continued involvement in the environment is depicted through images of mining operations, oil fields, the [[Navajo Generating Station]], the [[Glen Canyon Dam]], and [[atomic bomb]] detonations in a desert. Following the atomic bomb detonations, the next sequence begins with a shot of sunbathers on a beach, then pans to the [[San Onofre Nuclear Generating Station]] in the background. Shots of taxiing [[United Airlines]] [[Boeing 747]] aircraft and traffic patterns during [[rush hour]] are seen on a [[freeway]] and a shot of a large parking lot. This is followed with stock footage of Soviet tanks lined up in rows and a military aircraft, and an [[aircraft carrier]]. [[Time-lapse]] photography of shadows of clouds are seen moving across the skyscrapers. Shots of various [[housing projects]] in disrepair, and includes footage of the decay and demolition of the [[Pruitt-Igoe|Pruitt-Igoe housing project]] in [[St. Louis]]. The sequence ends with footage of the destruction of large buildings. A [[time-lapse]] shot of a crowd of people who appear to be waiting in a line. This is followed by shots of people walking along streets in [[slow motion]]. The next sequence begins with shots of buildings and a shot of a sunset reflected in the glass of a skyscraper. The sequence uses [[time-lapse]] photography of the activity of modern life. The events captured in this sequence involve people interacting with modern technology. The first shots are traffic patterns as seen from skyscrapers at night. This is followed by a composite shot of the moon passing behind a skyscraper. The next shots are closer shots of cars on a highway. The sun rises over the city and we see people hurrying to work. The film shows at regular speed the operation of machines packaging food. People are shown sorting mail, sewing [[jeans]], manufacturing televisions and doing other jobs with the use of modern technology. A shot of [[hot dogs]] being sent down rows of conveyors is followed by a shot of people moving up [[escalator]]s. The frenetic speed and pace of the cuts and music do not slow as shots of modern leisure are shown. People eat, play, shop and work at the same speed. The sequence begins to come full circle as the manufacture of cars in an [[assembly line]] [[factory]] is shown. More shots of highway traffic are shown, this time in daylight. The film shows the movement of cars, shopping carts, and televisions on an assembly line, and elevators moving from first-person perspective. The film then shows clips from various television shows being [[channel surfing|channel surfed]] in fast motion. The film, in slow motion, then shows several people reacting to being candidly filmed on the street. The camera stays on them until the moment when they acknowledge its presence by looking directly at it. The sequence then shows cars moving much faster than they were moving before. Pictures of microchips and satellite photography of metropolitan cities are shown, comparing the lay of each of them. Various shots of people are seen from all walks of modern life, from beggars to debutantes. The final sequence shows footage of a rocket lifting off, only to end up exploding after a few seconds. Editing suggest that there is only one rocket, while in fact two different events were used: The first batch of footage shows a [[Saturn V]] lifting off (Apollo 11), followed by footage of the May 1962 explosion of the first [[Atlas-Centaur]]. The camera follows a flaming rocket engine and a white vapor trail or smoke against a blue sky as the debris plummets toward the ground. The film concludes with another shot of desert rock art similar to the image at the beginning. Epilogue shows the translation of the titular [[Hopi]] word and of the prophecies sung in the last part of the soundtrack. ==Production== ===Background=== In 1972, [[Godfrey Reggio]], of the Institute for Regional Education (IRE), was working on a media campaign in [[Albuquerque, New Mexico]], which was sponsored by the [[American Civil Liberties Union]] (ACLU). The campaign involved [[privacy law|invasions of privacy]] and the use of technology to control behavior. Instead of making [[public service announcement]]s, which Reggio felt "had no visibility," advertising spots were purchased for television, radio, newspapers, and billboards.{{sfn|MacDonald|1992|p=383}} Over thirty billboards were used for the campaign, and one design featured a close-up of the [[human eye]], which Reggio described as a "horrifying image."{{sfn|MacDonald|1992|p=384}} To produce the television commercials the IRE hired cinematographer [[Ron Fricke]], who worked on the project for two years. The television advertisements aired during [[prime time]] programming and became so popular that viewers would call the television stations to learn when the next advertisement would be aired.{{sfn|MacDonald|1992|p=383}} Godfrey described the two-year campaign as "extraordinarily successful," and as a result, [[Methylphenidate|Ritalin (methylphenidate)]] was eliminated as a behavior-modifying drug in many New Mexico school districts.{{sfn|MacDonald|1992|p=384}} But after the campaign ended, the ACLU eventually withdrew its sponsorship, and the IRE unsuccessfully attempted to raise millions of dollars at a fundraiser in [[Washington, D.C.]] The institute only had $40,000 left in their budget, and Reggio was unsure how to use the small amount of funds. Fricke insisted to Reggio that the money could be used to produce a film, which led to the production of ''Koyaanisqatsi.''{{sfn|Gold|1984|p=63}} ===Filming=== [[File:Pruitt-Igoe-collapses.jpg|thumb|The demolition of the [[Pruitt–Igoe]] housing project in [[St. Louis, Missouri]] was one of the first scenes filmed once production began in 1975.]] Fricke and Reggio chose to shoot unscripted footage and edit it into an hour-long film.{{sfn|Gold|1984|p=63}} Production began in 1975 in [[St. Louis, Missouri]].{{sfn|MacDonald|1992|p=385}} [[16 mm film]] was used due to budget constraints, despite the preference to shoot with [[35 mm film]].{{sfn|MacDonald|1992|p=385}}{{sfn|MacDonald|1992|p=386}} Footage of the [[Pruitt–Igoe]] housing project was shot from a helicopter, and Fricke nearly passed out during filming, having never flown in a helicopter before.{{sfn|Gold|1984|p=63}} Reggio later chose to shoot in [[Los Angeles]] and [[New York City]]. As there was no formal script, Fricke shot whatever he felt would "look good on film".{{sfn|Gold|1984|p=64}} While filming in New York City, Fricke developed an idea to shoot portraits of people. A grey paper backdrop was displayed in [[Times Square]], and Fricke stood {{convert|10|ft|m|sigfig=1}} back with the camera. People walking by started posing for the camera, thinking it was a [[still camera]], and several shots from the setup ended up in the film. Reggio was not on location in Times Square when Fricke shot the footage and thought the idea of shooting portraits of people was "foolish". Upon viewing the footage, Reggio decided to devote an entire section of the film to portraits. The footage was [[photographic processing|processed]] with a special chemical to enhance the film's shadows and details, as all footage was shot only with existing lighting. The IRE's $40,000 was exhausted after the filming, and almost two cases of film had been used. The unedited footage was screened in [[Santa Fe, New Mexico]], but Fricke said it was "boring as hell" and there were "not that many good shots".{{sfn|Gold|1984|p=64}} Fricke later moved to [[Los Angeles]], and took a job as a waiter, unable to get a job in the film industry. While Fricke was working in Los Angeles, he edited the footage into a twenty-minute reel, but "without regard for message or political content".{{sfn|Gold|1984|p=64}} {{quote box|quote=I just shot anything that I thought would look good on film. Shooting bums, as well as buildings, didn't matter. It was all the same from my standpoint. I just shot the form of things.|source=—Ron Fricke{{sfn|Gold|1984|p=64}}|width=250px}} The IRE was continuously receiving funding and wanted to continue the project in 1976, using 35 mm film.{{sfn|Gold|1984|p=64}} After quitting his waiting job, Fricke traveled with a camera crew to the [[Four Corners]], which was chosen for filming for its "alien look".{{sfn|Gold|1984|p=66}} Due to the limited budget, Fricke shot with a 16 mm [[zoom lens]] onto 35 mm film. To compensate for the lens size, a 2× extender was added, which turned it into a full 35 mm zoom lens, allowing footage to be clearly captured onto 35 mm film. The two-week shoot included [[aerial shot|aerial footage]] taken from an airplane using a [[hand-held camera]] and ground footage taken using a [[tripod]]. The first aerial footage was too "shaky", so additional footage was taken from a camera mounted onto the airplane. Fricke traveled back to New York City in 1977, during which the [[New York City blackout of 1977|New York City blackout]] occurred. Footage of the blackout was filmed in [[Harlem]] and the [[South Bronx]], and the film was [[colorfulness|desaturated]] to match the appearance of the 16 mm footage.{{sfn|Gold|1984|p=66}} Reggio and Fricke came across [[time-lapse]] footage in "some low-visibility commercial work". They felt such footage was "the language [they] were missing", and collectively decided to implement time-lapse as a major part of the film to create "an experience of acceleration". For the time-lapse footage, Fricke purchased a [[Mitchell Camera|Mitchell]] camera,{{sfn|Gold|1984|p=66}} and built a motor with an [[intervalometer]], which was used to precisely move the camera between frames. The system was powered by a [[VRLA battery|gel cell battery]] that lasted for twelve hours, which enabled Fricke to shoot without the use of a [[electric generator|generator]].{{sfn|Gold|1984|p=68}} Most time-lapse shots were filmed at a [[frame rate]] of 1½ frames per second. Fricke wanted the footage to "look normal" and not contain any "gimmicky" special effects.{{sfn|Gold|1984|p=68}} The time-lapse shot overlooking the freeway in Los Angeles was filmed from the top of a building through a [[multiple exposure|double exposure]], with ten-second delay between frames. The first take was shot throughout the day for twelve hours, then the film was rewound and the same scene was shot at night for twenty minutes.{{sfn|Gold|1984|p=68}} The scene with the [[Boeing 747]] on the runway was filmed at [[Los Angeles International Airport]], and was the longest continuous shot in the film. Fricke and his [[focus puller]], Robert Hill, filmed at the airport every day for two weeks.{{sfn|Gold|1984|p=70}} To keep the shot of the 747 within the frame, the camera was slowly moved by increasing the voltage to the gear motors.{{sfn|Gold|1984|p=68}} In addition to footage shot by Fricke, some of the footage of people and traffic in New York City was shot by cinematographer [[Hilary Harris]]. During [[post-production]], Reggio was introduced to Harris' ''Organism'' (1975), which predominately features time-lapse footage of New York City streets. Reggio was impressed with Harris' work and subsequently hired him to work on ''Koyaanisqatsi''.{{sfn|MacDonald|1992|p=387}} Footage filmed by cinematographer [[Louis Schwartzberg]] was added into the cloud sequence, and additional stock footage was provided by [[MacGillivray Freeman Films]].{{sfn|Gold|1984|p=72}} While Reggio was working on post-production at the [[Samuel Goldwyn Studio]] in 1981,{{cite web|url=http://www.indiewire.com/article/interview_lone_giant_godfrey_reggios_naqoyqatsi/|title=INTERVIEW: Lone Giant: Godfrey Reggio's 'Naqoyqatsi{{'-}}|work=[[IndieWire]]|date=October 18, 2002|accessdate=April 26, 2011|first=Erin|last=Torneo}} he met film director [[Francis Ford Coppola]] through an associate from [[Zoetrope Studios]], Coppola's production company. Prior to shooting ''[[The Outsiders (film)|The Outsiders]]'' (1983) and ''[[Rumble Fish]]'' (1983), Coppola requested to see ''Koyaanisqatsi'', and Reggio arranged a private screening shortly after its completion.{{sfn|MacDonald|1992|p=399}} Coppola told Reggio that he was waiting for a film such as ''Koyaanisqatsi'' and that it was "important for people to see", so he added his name into the credits and helped present and distribute the film.{{sfn|Ramsey|1986|p=62}} Coppola also decided to introduce and end the film with footage of [[pictogram|pictographs]] from the Great Gallery at [[Horseshoe Canyon (Utah)|Horseshoe Canyon]] in [[Utah]], after visiting the site and becoming fascinated by the ancient sandstone murals.{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1986-08-10/news/vw-2386_1_horseshoe-canyon|title=The Past Comes to Life in Horseshoe Canyon|first=Charles|last=Hillinger|date=August 10, 1986|accessdate=April 26, 2011|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]}} ==Music== {{Infobox album | name = Koyaanisqatsi | type = Soundtrack | longtype = composed | artist = [[Philip Glass]] | cover = | alt = | released = 1983 | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Soundtrack]], [[film score]], [[Contemporary classical music|contemporary classical]], [[Minimalist music|minimalism]] | length = 46:25 | label = [[Island Records|Antilles/Island]] | producer = [[Kurt Munkacsi]] & [[Philip Glass]] | prev_title = [[Glassworks]] | prev_year = 1982 | next_title = [[The Photographer]] | next_year = 1983 }} The film's soundtrack by [[Philip Glass]] was released in 1983, after the release of the film. Even though the amount of music in the film was almost as long as the film itself, the soundtrack release was only 46 minutes long and featured only selections from the film's pieces. In 1998, Glass rerecorded the album through [[Nonesuch Records]] with a length of 73 minutes, 21 seconds. The rerecording of the album featured two additional tracks from the film, as well as extended versions of previous tracks from the original album. The album was released as a Philip Glass album titled ''Koyaanisqatsi'', rather than a soundtrack to the film. The music has become so popular that the [[Philip Glass Ensemble]] has toured the world, playing the music for ''Koyaanisqatsi'' live in front of the movie screen. The opening for "The Grid" begins with slow sustained notes on brass instruments. The music builds in speed and [[dynamics (music)|dynamics]] throughout the piece's 21 minutes. When the piece is at its fastest, it is characterized by a [[synthesizer]] playing the piece's bass line [[ostinato]]. Glass's music for the film is a highly recognizable example of the [[minimal music|minimalist]] school of composition, which is characterized by heavily repeated figures, simple structures, and a tonal (although not in the traditional [[common practice]] sense of the word) harmonic language. Glass was one of the first composers to employ minimalism in film scoring, paving the way for many future composers of that style.{{cite book |last=Eaton |first=Rebecca Marie Doran |date=May 2008 |title=Unheard Minimalisms: The Functions of the Minimalist Technique in Film Scores |url=https://repositories.lib.utexas.edu/bitstream/handle/2152/3839/eatonr88741.pdf |location=Austin, TX |publisher=The University of Texas at Austin }} The complete original soundtrack recording was released on CD in 2009 on Glass's own label [[Orange Mountain Music]].[http://www.philipglass.com/music/recordings/Koyaanisqatsi-09.php Complete Original Soundtrack (Orange Mountain Music) OMM 0058] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090608193034/http://www.philipglass.com/music/recordings/Koyaanisqatsi-09.php |date=June 8, 2009 }} {{album reviews |rev1=[[AllMusic]] |rev1score={{rating|5|5}}[http://www.allmusic.com/album/koyaanisqatsi-original-motion-picture-score-mw0000824705 Koyaanisqatsi (Original Motion Picture Score).] ''AllMusic.com''. Retrieved September 20, 2018. }} {{track listing |headline=''Koyaanisqatsi: Original Soundtrack Album from the Film'' (1983) |title1=Koyaanisqatsi |length1=3:30 |title2=Vessels |length2=8:03 |title3=Cloudscape |length3=4:41 |title4=Pruit Igoe |length4=7:02 |title5=The Grid |length5=14:50 |title6=Prophecies |length6=8:10 |total_length=46:16 }} {{track listing |headline=''Koyaanisqatsi'' (1998) |title1=Koyaanisqatsi |length1=3:28 |title2=Organic |length2=7:43 |title3=Cloudscape |length3=4:34 |title4=Resource |length4=6:39 |title5=Vessels |length5=8:05 |title6=Pruit Igoe |length6=7:53 |title7=The Grid |length7=21:23 |title8=Prophecies |length8=13:36 |total_length=73:21 }} {{track listing |headline=''Koyaanisqatsi: Original Motion Picture Score'' (2009) |title1=Koyaanisqatsi |length1=3:27 |title2=Organic |length2=4:57 |title3=Clouds |length3=4:38 |title4=Resource |length4=6:36 |title5=Vessels |length5=8:13 |title6=Pruitt Igoe |length6=7:51 |title7=Pruitt Igoe Coda |length7=1:17 |title8=SloMo People |length8=3:20 |title9=The Grid Introduction |length9=3:24 |title10=The Grid |length10=18:06 |title11=Microchip |length11=1:47 |title12=Prophecies |length12=10:34 |title13=Translations and Credits |length13=2:11 |total_length=76:21 }} {{clear}} ==Meaning== Reggio stated that the ''Qatsi'' films are intended to simply create an experience and that "it is up [to] the viewer to take for himself/herself what it is that [the film] means." He also said that "these films have never been about the effect ''of'' technology, ''of'' industry ''on'' people. It's been that everyone: politics, education, things of the financial structure, the nation state structure, language, the culture, religion, all of that exists within the host of technology. So it's not the effect ''of'', it's that everything exists within [technology]. It's not that we ''use'' technology, we ''live'' technology. Technology has become as ubiquitous as the air we breathe ..." According to ''[[Hopi Dictionary: Hopìikwa Lavàytutuveni]]'', the [[Hopi language|Hopi]] word ''koyaanisqatsi'' ({{IPA-all|kojɑːnisˈkɑtsi|Hopi pronunciation:}}){{sfn|Hopi Dictionary Project|1998|p=863}} is defined as "life of moral corruption and turmoil" or "life out of balance".{{sfn|Hopi Dictionary Project|1998|p=154}} The prefix ''koyaanis–'' means "corrupted" or "chaotic", and the word ''qatsi'' means "life" or "existence",{{sfn|Hopi Dictionary Project|1998|p=463}} literally translating ''koyaanisqatsi'' as "chaotic life".{{sfn|Hopi Dictionary Project|1998|p=154}} The film also defines the word as "crazy life", "life in turmoil", "life disintegrating", and "a state of life that calls for another way of living".{{cite web|url=http://www.koyaanisqatsi.org/films/k_defs.php|title=Koyaanisqatsi definitions|work=Koyaanisqatsi.org|publisher=Institute for Regional Education|accessdate=May 9, 2011}} In the score by [[Philip Glass]], the word "Koyaanisqatsi" is chanted at the beginning and end of the film in an "otherworldly"{{cite book|last=Neveldine|first=Robert Burns|title=Bodies at Risk: Unsafe Limits in Romanticism and Postmodernism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UcJGLUMD-boC&pg=PA112|year=1998|publisher=SUNY Press|isbn=9780791436493|page=112}} dark, sepulchral ''[[basso profondo]]'' by singer Albert de Ruiter over a solemn, four-bar organ-passacaglia bassline. Three [[Hopi prophecies]] sung by a choral ensemble during the latter part of the "Prophecies" movement are translated just prior to the end credits: * "If we dig precious things from the land, we will invite disaster." * "Near the day of Purification, there will be cobwebs spun back and forth in the sky." * "A container of ashes might one day be thrown from the sky, which could burn the land and boil the oceans." During the end titles, the film gives [[Jacques Ellul]], [[Ivan Illich]], [[David Monongye]], [[Guy Debord]], and [[Leopold Kohr]] credit for inspiration. Moreover, amongst the consultants to the director are listed such names as Jeffrey Lew, T.A. Price, Belle Carpenter, Cybelle Carpenter, [[Langdon Winner]], and Barbara Pecarich. ==Releases== ===Theatrical distribution=== ''Koyaanisqatsi'' premiered at the [[Santa Fe Film Festival]] on April 28, 1982.{{cite web|url=https://movies.yahoo.com/photos/celebrities/gallery/3322/on-this-day-in-movie-history-#photo9|title=On This Day in Movie History ...|work=[[Yahoo! Movies]]|date=April 28, 2011|accessdate=September 3, 2011}} It was screened later that year at the [[Telluride Film Festival]] in August and at the [[New York Film Festival]] in September.{{cite web|url=http://www.telluridefilmfestival.org/photoscroller.html|title=9th Festival – 1982|publisher=[[Telluride Film Festival]]|accessdate=September 3, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120320120751/http://www.telluridefilmfestival.org/photoscroller.html|archive-date=March 20, 2012|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}{{cite news|title=20th New York Film Festival|date=September 12, 1983|page=H14|work=[[The New York Times]]}} [[Triumph Films]] offered to [[Film distributor|distribute]] the film, but Reggio turned down the offer as he wanted to work with a smaller company so he could be more involved with the release. He chose Island Alive as the distributor, a company newly formed in 1983 by [[Chris Blackwell]] of [[Island Records]],{{cite web|title=Our Founder: Chris Blackwell|url=http://www.islandoutpost.com/about_us/our_founder/|publisher=Island Outpost|accessdate=September 4, 2011}} and ''Koyaanisqatsi'' was the company's first release. Select theaters distributed a pamphlet that defined the title and the Hopi prophecies sung in the film, as well as a copy of the soundtrack from Island Records. The first theatrical run featured four-track [[Dolby Stereo]] sound, while later runs featured [[monaural]] sound. The film's initial [[limited release]] began in [[San Francisco]] at the [[Castro Theatre]] on April 27, 1983.{{cite web|url=http://www.joblo.com/releases.php?mode=theatrical&month=April&year=1983|title=Theatrical Release Dates – April 1983|work=[[JoBlo.com]]|accessdate=September 4, 2011}} The producers spent $6,500 on marketing the initial release, which grossed $46,000 throughout its one-week run, and was the highest-grossing film in the [[San Francisco Bay Area]] that week. It was released in [[Los Angeles]] a month later where it grossed $300,000 at two theaters within 15 weeks. Additional releases in select cities throughout the United States continued in September 1983, beginning with a release in New York City on September 15. In mid-October, ''Koyaanisqatsi'' was released onto 40–50 screens throughout the country.{{cite journal|title=The Marketing of Koyaanisqatsi: Market It? I Can't Even Pronounce It!|work=[[Boxoffice (magazine)|Boxoffice]]|date=December 1983|volume=119|issue=12|first=Karen|last=Kreps|pages=68, 70|url=http://www.boxofficemagazine.com/the_vault/issue_page?issue_id=1983-12-1&page_no=72#page_start|accessdate=September 4, 2011}} A 1991 issue of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' listed ''Koyaanisqatsi''{{'s}} box office gross at $3.2 million.{{cite journal|title=Variety magazine |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=February 25, 1991|pages=5–6}} ===Home media=== ''Koyaanisqatsi'' was originally released on [[VHS]] and [[laserdisc]] by [[Michael Nesmith]]'s [[Pacific Arts Corporation|Pacific Arts Video]]. The [[film rights|rights]] to ''Koyaanisqatsi'' were passed through various multinational entertainment companies, which eventually prevented a home video release. IRE enforced their legal and contractual rights by creating a [[United States federal courts|federal court]] [[lawsuit]]. IRE distributed a privately issued release of the film on DVD. The release was available to those who made a donation of at least $180 to IRE, and was distributed in a sleeve that was signed by Reggio.{{cite web |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20001109061600/http://www.koyaanisqatsi.org/howyoucanhelp/help_IRE.las |url=http://www.koyaanisqatsi.org/howyoucanhelp/help_IRE.las |title=How You Can Help: Getting Involved |accessdate=November 21, 2016 |work=Koyaanisqatsi.org |publisher=IRE |archivedate=November 9, 2000}} [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer|Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer (MGM)]] eventually received the rights to the film, and ''Koyaanisqatsi'' was released on DVD by [[MGM Home Entertainment]] on September 18, 2002, coinciding with the release of ''[[Naqoyqatsi]]'' (2002). Both films were available in a two-disc box set. Each DVD includes a documentary with interviews by Reggio and Glass and trailers for the [[Qatsi trilogy|''Qatsi'' trilogy]].{{cite web|url=http://www.dvdtalk.com/dvdsavant/s582reggio.html|title=Koyaanisqatsi & Powaqqatsi|first=Glenn|last=Erickson|work=DVD Savant|accessdate=June 6, 2011}} Unlike the IRE release, which featured the film in the [[open matte]] format in which it was filmed, the MGM release was in cropped into a [[widescreen]] aspect as it was originally presented in theaters.{{cite web|series=Comparison between the two versions|url=http://www.dvdbeaver.com/film/DVDCompare2/koyaanisqatsi.htm|accessdate=June 6, 2011|title=Koyaanisqatsi DVD Comparison|work=DVD Beaver}} On January 13, 2012, a Blu-ray version (screen ratio 16:9) was released in Germany.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.de/dp/B0063NT8UG|title=German Blu-ray release|work=Amazon.de|accessdate=April 9, 2012}} The Blu-ray was also released in Australia by [[Umbrella Entertainment]] on March 22, 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.umbrellaent.com.au/p-3302-koyaanisqatsi-blu-ray.aspx|title=Australian Blu-ray release|work=Umbrellaent.com.au|accessdate=30 May 2012}} In December 2012, [[The Criterion Collection|Criterion]] released in the US a remastered Blu-ray and DVD of ''Koyaanisqatsi'', as part of a box set containing the ''Qatsi'' Trilogy. ==Reception== ''Koyaanisqatsi'' has a score of 89% on [[Rotten Tomatoes]] out of 18 reviews.{{cite web |url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/koyaanisqatsi_life_out_of_balance |title=Koyaanisqatsi – Life Out of Balance (1982) |accessdate=2013-04-26 |work=Rotten Tomatoes}} In 1983, the film was entered into the [[33rd Berlin International Film Festival]].{{cite web |url=http://www.berlinale.de/en/archiv/jahresarchive/1983/02_programm_1983/02_Programm_1983.html |title=Berlinale: 1983 Programme |accessdate=2010-11-17 |work=berlinale.de}} In 2000, ''Koyaanisqatsi'' was selected for preservation in the United States [[National Film Registry]] by the [[Library of Congress]] as being "culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant".{{cite press release|url=http://www.koyaanisqatsi.org/aboutus/press.php|title=Koyaanisqatsi Added to the National Film Registry|date=December 31, 2000|accessdate=May 8, 2011}} ''Koyaanisqatsi'' is followed by the sequels ''[[Powaqqatsi]]'' and ''[[Naqoyqatsi]]'' and the shorts ''[[Anima Mundi (film)|Anima Mundi]]'' and ''Evidence.'' ''Naqoyqatsi'' was completed after a lengthy delay caused by funding problems and premiered in the United States on October 18, 2002. The film's [[cinematographer]], [[Ron Fricke]], went on to direct ''[[Baraka (film)|Baraka]]'', a [[pure cinema]] movie which is often compared to ''Koyaanisqatsi''. ==Influences== * The film inspired the Belgian post-rock band [[We Stood Like Kings]] to write a new soundtrack under the title USA 1982, released in 2017 on the German label Kapitän Platte and presented at the cultural venue [[Centre for Fine Arts, Brussels]] in October 2017. * The trailer for ''[[Grand Theft Auto IV]]'' resembles the style of the film, featuring different shots of the fictional Liberty City, with the track "Pruit Igoe" in the background.{{Citation|last=Ndr *|title=GTA IV trailer|date=2007-03-29|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wGXCyMrZ1jA|accessdate=2018-02-12}} * The 2009 film ''[[Watchmen (film)|Watchmen]]'' accompanies the [[origin story]] of its character [[Doctor Manhattan]] with a montage of the pieces "Prophecies" and "Pruit Igoe", and features the same tracks in its trailer.{{Cite news|url=http://movies.about.com/od/watchmen/a/watchmen-songs.htm|title=What Songs Appear on the 'Watchmen' Movie Soundtrack?|work=ThoughtCo|access-date=2018-02-12}} * The film inspired the album ''Music To Films'' by Dr. Atmo and [[Oliver Lieb]], released on the record label [[FAX +49-69/450464]]. The music is completely synchronized to the film. *The film inspired filmmaker Param P. Tomanec to direct experimental documentary ''Rasa Yatra'' (2012). * The film's title song was featured in two episodes of the TV series ''[[Scrubs (TV series)|Scrubs]]''. The first time was in "[[My New God]]" when the [[Janitor (Scrubs)|Janitor]] gave the "evil eye" to J.D. The second time was in "[[My Chopped Liver]]" when the [[Janitor (Scrubs)|Janitor]] gave the "evil eye" to [[Carla (Scrubs)|Carla]] accompanied by [[The Todd|Todd]], [[Laverne Roberts|Laverne]] and [[Ted (Scrubs)|Ted]].{{cite episode |title=My New God |episodelink=List of Scrubs episodes#Season 5: 2006 |series=Scrubs |serieslink=Scrubs (TV series) |network=[[NBC]] |season=5 |number=5 }}{{cite episode |title=My Chopped Liver |episodelink=List of Scrubs episodes#Season 5: 2006 |series=Scrubs |serieslink=Scrubs (TV series) |network=[[NBC]] |season=5 |number=17}} * The title song appears in Season Six of the CW series ''[[Gilmore Girls]]'', in the episode "We've Got Magic to Do". Kirk performs an interpretive dance as the song plays in the background. * The chanted "koyaanisqatsi" lyric from the film's title song was [[parody|parodied]] in [[P. D. Q. Bach]]'s "Prelude to Einstein on the Fritz" (itself a pun on the title of the opera ''[[Einstein on the Beach]]'' composed by Philip Glass), replaced with the lyric "coy hotsy-totsy".{{cite news |url=http://www.villagevoice.com/1999-01-19/music/classical-trash/ |title=Classical Trash |work=[[The Village Voice]] |first=Kyle |last=Gann |date=1999-01-19 |accessdate=2008-05-28}} * Madonna's video for "[[Ray of Light (song)|Ray of Light]]" visually resembles ''Koyaanisqatsi''.{{cite news |url=http://www.beyondrobson.com/music/2006/02/glass_is_philip_qe_not_halfempty/ |title=Glass is Philip; QE not half-empty |work=Beyond Robson |date=2006-02-24 |accessdate=2008-05-29 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081007151738/http://www.beyondrobson.com/music/2006/02/glass_is_philip_qe_not_halfempty/ |archive-date=October 7, 2008 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} * The film's title theme also inspired the soundtrack to the classic 1987 video game ''[[Delta (video game)|Delta]]'', which became one of the best known video game soundtracks by [[Rob Hubbard]]. * A 2010 episode of ''[[The Simpsons]]'', "[[Stealing First Base]]", features a parody [[Itchy & Scratchy]] film entitled ''Koyaanis-Scratchy: Death out of Balance''.{{cite news |last1=Short |first1=Hogan |title=11 Films You Didn't Know Were Perfect to Watch on 4/20 |url=http://beatroute.ca/2017/04/17/11-films-didnt-know-perfect-watch-420/ |accessdate=25 August 2018 |work=BeatRoute Magazine |date=17 April 2017}} * The 2013 comedy film ''[[Alan Partridge: Alpha Papa]]'' opens with shots of the Norfolk coastline similar to style to ''Koyaanisqatsi'', with the title track also playing. * Clips from the film were used in The B-52's music video for "[[Rock Lobster]]". *Possibly, the film's iconic sped-up city imagery was inspired by the title sequence for [[Jack Garfein]]'s 1961 cult classic ''[[Something Wild (1961 film)|Something Wild]]''. It also states that the term is used "in the names of certain massacres of history".[[Oxford English Dictionary]] Massacre, n. The first recorded use in English of the word ''massacre'' in the name of an event is due to [[Christopher Marlow]] who in c. 1600 referred to what is now known as the [[St. Bartholomew's Day massacre]] as "The massacre at Paris""Marlowe (c. 1600) (''title'') The massacre at Paris". [[Oxford English Dictionary]] Massacre, n. The purpose of the list is to trace such of the term "massacre" specifically. There are many alternative terms with similar connotations, such as [[:wikt:butchery|butchery]], [[:wikt:carnage|carnage]], [[:wikt:bloodbath|bloodbath]], [[:wikt:mass killing|mass killing]], [[wikt:atrocity|atrocity]], etc. as well as euphemisms such as ''[[Sicilian Vespers|Vespers]]'', ''[[Blutgericht]]'' or "attack", "incident", "tragedy" (etc.), use of which are outside the scope of this list. The event was almost immediately termed a "massacre" and used for propagandistic purposes, especially by [[Samuel Adams]]. A pamphlet with the title ''A short narrative of the horrid massacre in Boston, perpetrated in the evening of the fifth day of March, 1770, by soldiers of the 29th regiment, which with the 14th regiment were then quartered there; with some observations on the state of things prior to that catastrophe'' was printed still in 1770. Appositional "Boston massacre" was in use by the early 1800s (Benjamin Austin, ''Constitutional Republicanism, in Opposition to Fallacious Federalism'', 1803, [https://books.google.ch/books?id=fvY-AAAAYAAJ&pg=PA314 p. 314]). The term "[[Massacre Day]]" for the annual remembrance held during 1771–1783 dates to the late 19th century (Augusta De Grasse Stevens, ''Old Boston: An American Historical Romance'', 1888, p. 126) The 1772 "Massacre Day of Oration" by [[Joseph Warren]] was originally titled ''An Oration Delivered March 5th, 1772. [[File:Manannans Cloak - An Anthology of Manx Literature.jpg|thumb|'Manannan's Cloak: An Anthology of Manx Literature' edited by [[Robert Corteen Carswell]]]] '''Manx literature''' is literature in the [[Manx language]].
==History== The earliest datable text in Manx (preserved in 18th century [[manuscript]]s), a poetic history of the [[Isle of Man]] from the introduction of [[Christianity]], dates to the 16th century at the latest.
Christianity has been an overwhelming influence on Manx literature. Religious literature was common, but surviving secular writing much rarer. The New Testament was first published in 1767. The [[Book of Common Prayer]] and [[Bible]] were translated into Manx and published in 1610 and again in 1765. The first Manx Bible was printed between 1771 and 1775 and is the source and standard for modern Manx [[orthography]]. It was a collective translation undertaken by most the Manx clergy under the editorship of Philip Moore. Further editions followed in 1777 and a revised edition by the British and Foreign Bible Society 1819. A tradition of {{lang|gv|carvals}}, religious songs or [[Carol (music)|carols]], developed, probably with its roots in the pre-Reformation period. Until the 18th century, the authors of {{lang|gv|carvals}} were generally clergy, but in the 19th century new words would be put to popular tunes for use in churches and chapels.
The first printed work in Manx, {{lang|gv|Coyrle Sodjeh}}, dates from 1707: a translation of a Prayer Book [[catechism]] in English by [[Thomas Wilson (bishop)|Bishop Thomas Wilson]].
''Pargys Caillit'' was an abridged Manx version of [[Paradise Lost]] by [[John Milton]] published in 1796 by [[Thomas Christian]], vicar of Marown 1780-1799.
[[Edward Faragher]], ({{lang|gv|Neddy Beg Hom Ruy}}, 1831–1908) of [[Cregneash]] has been considered the last important native writer of Manx. From the age of 26, he wrote poetry, often on religious subjects, some of which were printed in the ''Mona's Herald'' and the ''Cork Eagle''. Some of his stories are reminiscences of his life as a fisherman, and in 1901 {{lang|gv|Skeealyn Aesop}}, translations of selected [[Aesop]]'s Fables,<ref>{{cite book | title = Skeealyn ‘sy Ghailck | last = Faragher | first = Edward | publisher = Yn Çheshaght Ghailckagh | origyear = 1948 | year = 1973 | chapter = Editorial note (Basil Megaw, director of the Manx Museum) }}</ref> was published.
A large number of traditional Manx language songs and ballads were collected by the antiquarian and historian [[Arthur William Moore|A.W. Moore]] which he published in ''Manx Carols'' (1891) and ''Manx Ballads and Music'' (1896).
With the [[Language revival|revival]] of Manx, new literature has appeared, including {{lang|gv|Contoyryssyn Ealish ayns Cheer ny Yindyssyn}} a Manx translation of ''[[Alice's Adventures in Wonderland|Alice in Wonderland]]'' by [[Brian Stowell]], published in 1990. In March 2006 the first full-length Manx novel<ref>[http://www.iomonline.co.im/ViewArticle2.aspx?SectionID=1143&ArticleID=1397570 ''Isle of Man Today'' article on {{lang|gv|Dunveryssyn yn Tooder-Folley}}] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060826083707/http://www.iomonline.co.im/ViewArticle2.aspx?SectionID=1143&ArticleID=1397570 |date=2006-08-26 }}</ref> was published: {{lang|gv|Dunveryssyn yn Tooder-Folley}} (''The Vampire Murders''), also by Brian Stowell.
